text: no council of wise men sat down before the Industrial Revolution and decided whether or not it was good for humanity, and im fairly sure they would have decided no because their time preference would have voted for their own comfort over abundance for their descendants

absolutely none of this is true, it’s the highest status of priesthood for past several years to care about ai safety and alignment. people incessantly talk about tradeoffs and risks at the big labs. you get destroyed on social media for launching something off color

your take is actually alarmingly wrong. people turn down 100s of millions of dollars from meta super intelligence labs because of concerns about ethics and the aura loss they’d suffer from going there, to the point where I’m not sure they’re even examining their opportunity cost

circular logic, think about it, why is it low status to go to? people look down upon it as the slop machine at the end of time and feel the moral quandary it presents, directly in contradiction to your original post. you're not making your case

actually yes so this is not a good counterargument. virological gain of function research is most likely extremely stupid. the difference is that even in the best case all you have is a very strong virus that can kill many and then maybe you can study some of its properties

if this was true in the slightest people would look down on those who leave oai/anthropic to go work at gdm which is far older than meta. but nobody does, because you are obviously wrong

look at the rhetorical sleight of hand you are using, implying that i don't care about or disbelieve in existential risks because i think the document called "superintelligence statement" is dumb

this is not a good rebuttal. i'm saying the consensus mechanism would have failed to make the right decision for cases where proceeding was indeed safe and benevolent, and your response is that this one is actually not safe, which says nothing about quality of the mechanism. 

i do not believe in the 'scientific consensus mechanism' as a term of law for gating civilization scale change. it is frequently weaponized in politics to get whatever either side wants, for arresting change, and i would not sign this statement, not that anybody cares

disagree with this take that climate change is primarily incident on the global poor. technological capitalism has pulled billions out of poverty. 

bangladesh’ gdp per capita is 13x higher than it was in 1980. whatever climate impact they face is minor in comparison

industry is a thermodynamic process that creates useful work for humanity and exudes waste heat. if the externalities of the heat are less bad (and decreasing over time) than the useful work, then it was all worthwhile. we should all be less guilty
losing some land to the sea could very well be worth becoming 10x richer
